video.title: Microservice Architecture and System Design with Python & Kubernetes – Full Course
video.description:
Learn about software system design and microservices. This course is a hands-on approach to learning about microservice architectures and distributed systems using Python, Kubernetes, RabbitMQ, MongoDB, mySQL.

✏️ Course from Kantan Coding. Check out his channel: https://www.youtube.com/channel/UC5UgemAz061hkjTFHOfxNpg

💻 Code: https://github.com/selikapro/microservices-python

Kubernetes API Reference: https://kubernetes.io/docs/reference/kubernetes-api/

⭐️ Contents ⭐️
(0:00:00) Intro
(0:01:02) Overview 
(0:02:47) Installation & Setup?
(0:10:16) Auth Service Code
(0:32:25) Auth Flow Overview & JWTs
(0:53:04) Auth Service Deployment
(0:56:08) Auth Dockerfile
(1:20:05) Kubernetes
(1:37:26) Gateway Service Code
(1:42:34) MongoDB & GridFs
(1:47:04) Architecture Overview (RabbitMQ)
(1:49:50) Synchronous Interservice Communication
(1:50:49) Asynchronous Interservice Communication
(1:53:19) Strong Consistency
(1:54:07) Eventual Consistency
(2:19:16) RabbitMQ
(2:21:16) Gateway Service Deployment
(2:35:34) Kubernetes Ingress
(2:46:28) Kubernetes StatefulSet
(2:51:18) RabbitMQ Deployment
(3:09:35) Converter Service Code
(3:33:43) Converter Service Deployment
(4:21:09) Checkpoint
(4:22:11) Update Gateway Service
(4:31:46) Notification Service Code
(4:43:24) Notification Service Deployment
(4:51:55) Sanity Check
(5:05:54) End

⭐️ References ⭐️
https://www.mongodb.com/docs/
https://www.rabbitmq.com/documentation.html
https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/architecture/patterns/competing-consumers
https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/architecture/microservices/design/interservice-communication
https://cloud.google.com/datastore/docs/articles/balancing-strong-and-eventual-consistency-with-google-cloud-datastore

🎉 Thanks to our Champion and Sponsor supporters:
👾 Nattira Maneerat
👾 Heather Wcislo
👾 Serhiy Kalinets
👾 Erdeniz Unvan
👾 Justin Hual
👾 Agustín Kussrow
👾 Otis Morgan

--

Learn to code for free and get a developer job: https://www.freecodecamp.org

Read hundreds of articles on programming: https://freecodecamp.org/news

topLevelComment.author: Kantan Coding
topLevelComment.text:
Thanks fcc for all that you do for this community! I hope that you all can learn from this real world example project. I work on similar architectures in my work as a backend SWE. If you are interested in more content from me feel free to subscribe to my channel: https://www.youtube.com/@kantancoding

And here is the git repo(code) for this tutorial: https://github.com/selikapro/microservices-python

topLevelComment.author: Tianxin Li
topLevelComment.text: For those who are using pure digits as the mysql password, you need to use double quote for the MYSQL_PASSWORD value in secret.yaml to force it to a string type so your kubectl apply -f ./ wouldn't generate any error.

But it has required some google-searches and experimenting. On my Win10-laptop I ended up using PowerShell instead of WSL. Upside is that you learn a lot of operational skills.

replies.author: Russ

replies.author: Tim Richardson
replies.text: Windows is a nightmare for this, you will be at the mercy of bad ports that no one takes seriously, and that's the best case. Use WSL or a linux VM. If you are interested in this type of software building, Windows is not in your future.

topLevelComment.author: Omni
topLevelComment.text: Well nice to see a video about architecture and I get that's your focus. But I'm not sure showing vulnerable examples (SQL injection) and other things from the 90ties (direct sql calls instead of using ORM) do a good service to noobs.

replies.author: Jeasen Jimble
replies.text:
I understand your point and if you meant to say that one should by no means be lulled into a false sense of security just because one has done something against sql-injections, then I agree.

However, I would like to add something:
ORMs are NOT a panacea and are often a straight path to hell. Like ORMs, prepared statements have their place in a developer's toolbox, especially for micro services. If there is no ORM, it can't cause trouble and it can't be exploited.

Furthermore, security vulnerabilities have no expiry date. They can and often are patched, but far too often they are not, for various reasons. Knowing attack vectors basically never hurts, even if they are not currently used in any campaign or commodity malware.

Basically, it's like " not dying": just because we are not exposed to certain dangers as much these days, doesn't mean that we should lightly expose ourselves to them or even ignore them.

replies.author: Kantan Coding
replies.text:
Hey! Thanks for the feedback! So in short, the code is NOT vulnerable to SQL injection. Here’s a good article that explains how to prevent sql injection in Python which might clear things up for you: https://realpython.com/prevent-python-sql-injection/

On the topic of ORMs, it seems that your opinion is that they should always be used? I’d have to disagree with you there as there are many reasons why one would choose not to use an ORM. As you already mentioned, my focus was the overall architecture. Incorporating an ORM into the mix would have been overly cumbersome while contributing nothing to the viewers understanding of the architecture.

replies.author: Pieter Kuppens
replies.text:
That's also my question! How did you set up vim to use pylint? Is the checking 'live' or do you use a keyboard shortcut?

Or on a completely different level, is there a config for Visual Studio Code, which seems a bit more user-friendly and cross-platform. Though I'm a dinosaur that actually knows and uses vi(m) when I'm working in text terminals on UNIX-based systems.

PS. I'll forgive that you store passwords in plain text instead of with a salted hash ;)

replies.author: linucksrox
replies.text: You would generally want to store files on something like s3 as opposed to blobs in a database, although there are some valid use cases for that but probably not mp3 files. Btw you could be using a better encoding option like ogg for audio but that's a whole 'nother conversation.
